links.quantification: Tenure security → ₹50K Cr infrastructure investment unlocked → 65M slum residents gain legal access to services → urbanization formalized
Property rights → piped water connections viable → 80% slum households gain access (vs. 30% informal) → ₹10K Cr tanker costs avoided
Formalization → metered electricity → theft reduction 60%→20% → ₹15K Cr DISCOM revenue recovery → grid investment enabled
Service access → waste collection coverage 40%→95% → ₹3K Cr municipal expenditure justified → open dumping eliminated
Political resistance: Tenure threatens slum vote banks → politicians oppose formalization → 10-year implementation gridlock
LPG access → cooking fuel shift from biomass → indoor PM2.5 -70% → respiratory disease -40% → health-tenure virtuous cycle
links.citation: Thesis: Tenure indoor air quality cascade

links.quantification: Requires inclusive planning: Tenure only sustainable with in-situ upgrades → ₹30K Cr slum redevelopment (no displacement) prerequisite
Via sanitation: Piped water → toilet use increases → open defecation waste burning -80% → air quality improves
Via affordability: Metered electricity ₹5/kWh (vs. ₹15 informal) → household energy costs -60% → ₹8K Cr consumer savings
Via connectivity: Tenure enables transit investments → 500 bus routes extended to slums → ₹5K Cr mobility infrastructure
Via collection: Open burning -90% → PM2.5 decline → respiratory hospitalizations -30% → ₹2K Cr health savings
